23529908.review:
A solid platformer at a good price. The game reminds me of a variety of things; perhaps the best summary is something like "Symphony of the Night meets Dark Souls". There are two gameplay modes (survival, which plays more like a roguelike apparently and classic which is a more traditional Metroidvania) and three difficulties for each which provides a decent array of challenges for any player. Boss fights require pattern recognition and decent skill, and searching for upgrades, which are scattered throughout the maps through hidden "souls" and in shops, with a variety of upgrades and tools you can grab to either make fights easier or explore faster. There are a variety of skills that can enhance your base abilities, with a passive bonus for points in each tree supplementing the individual elements of each tree. Dying costs you all your money (by default, which you can mitigate with starting money found through upgrades) and shunts you back to a 3D printer to respawn. You can travel between these, which alleviates the walking required, and save your upgrades and loot here (on Classic). 

You can acquire a variety of primary weapons and quite a few different sub weapons, which provide a variety of strategies ranging from beam weapons to deployable drones. You can also do your traditional movement upgrades to move more quickly and reach new areas, though these are mostly optional (I'd recommend them though). There are plenty of secrets scattered throughout the various maps, some with great benefits like more HP or ammo and others that are just easter eggs. The writing is decent and the voice acting, while not perfect, is fun. The subtitles are not super accurate, but item descriptions are satisfactory and overall the game's sense of humor lasts well through the end, leaving me wanting mroe.

The boss fights are decently clever, and there are various mechanics that force you to adapt and use different weapons and strategies for each fight. None of these fights are too rediculously hard, and sometimes they can be a bit too easy, especially if you've gotten as many upgrades as you can. Unfortunately, these can't be repeated in the course of a story run, and if there's a boss rush mode or a way to repeat the fights I missed it. More interesting are arena fights in the form of "alarms". These are either triggered as you progress through areas or as optional encounters off to the side in areas. As you repeat alarms, the difficulty level increases, resulting in more (and often times more dangerous) enemies. 

The soundtrack, while not phenomenal, is solid and immersive and doesn't get annoyingly repetitive, unlike some others. The sound design is nothing extraordinary either, but things sound like they "should" based on other games, so it's nothing to worry about.

Now for a summary:

Pros:
Cool upgrade system that encourages collection and synergizing.
Gameplay is solid and difficulty is neither too hard nor too easy (based on a medium playthough).
Story is good and compelling.
Writing and humor are engaging and amusing without becoming heavyhanded. (I was surprised by the ending, which is rare, although it's not the most unique ending I've ever seen.)

Cons:
Too short; I could stand twice as much content easily (again, it's worth the price, but I liked it so much that I'm left wanting more)
No new game plus; even if just repeating with your unlocked "geekies". it would be nice to play through again, even if just with a few nods to your previous run.
Difficulty is middle of the road, but some segments may be too difficult/frustrating for some players or to easy/repetitive for others. 

Don't let the length of the "Cons" section fool you; I recommend this game readily, and look forward to more content from this indie developer.

Verdict: B+

23517577.review:
Ghost 1.0 is a new entry to the metroidvania genre, and it comes with smooth controls, intense fights and a selection of different game-play choices.

Read more...

Fran is the main developer of Ghost 1.0, with only receiving assistance for art, music and sound effects leaving the remaining to him. Ghost has been in development for 2.5 years and was released on Steam on the 7th of June 2016.

The game begins with two hackers who are hiring an agent called Ghost (the player) to sneak into the Nakamura Space Station and once on-board, to begin searching for anything which would display their secrets. Your tasks become clearer as the story develops and you discover the entire space station.

Unlike the usual type of game where you'd just control one character and shoot everything in-sight, Ghost works differently as she has a special ability to leave her body, which is a drone, and control any other drone she pleases to help her accomplish the mission in a safer and easier manner.

In this game you'll continually be harassed by drones, turrets and lasers as you move swiftly from room to room, you will constantly need to focus on dodging incoming attacks while shooting your own shots, waves, beams and bombs.

Ghost 1.0 Pipes

Ghost 1.0 is a game where you may find yourself continually grinding waves of enemies in order to accumulate high amounts of currency to purchase upgrades and guns which is vital for boss battles. There are over 300 rooms to explore, 35 weapons to purchase and 40 upgrades, items and power ups. There's a lot to collect and purchase.

There is a skill tree which doesn't work in the same RPG element as the game states, instead you'll slowly build up these points as you explore and find pickups. There are over 60 different abilities which the user can put points into but each run they can only utilise 20 of them and there's also no resetting your point selection, so chose wisely.

Once you've completed the initial classic game mode you can also select to play survival, where the gameplay runs at a much faster pace but is much more harsh in terms of punishment for death.

The graphics in the game are extremely well done in cut scenes and gameplay with a fitting selection of voice acting, music and sound effects which give the game a professional and completed feel.

23490807.review:
Ghost 1.0       (Things I wish I knew earlier list at end)
I have to recognize that I have some bias towards this game.  The creators first game (Unepic) was really enjoyed with hours and hours of time, and this game was watched and followed.  A friend saw my interest and picked me up a copy the first day it was out, and I've been enjoying the game immensely.  While I'm only into the second zone, game play has been both experienced and watched.

I like the game.  This has been an enjoyable experience of slowly gaining power to defeat the enemies.  This game is definitely worth the price, and looks great.

Combat:  Combat is fun and precise.  I use a mouse and keyboard and enjoy the feel of running, jumping, shooting, and rolling presented in the game.

Upgrades:  Experiencing 7 guns, 5 items, 4 geek secrets, 10 upgrades, and 5 skill points I've enjoyed the leveling scale.  Items and upgrades feel appropriate with easy gains giving small benefits (example, collecting all souls in a room may provide +10 max health).  Expensive upgrades like guns definitely feel worth the price.  The skills provide a good choice variety where the people I've seen play pick different options then myself.  

Platforming:  Depending on your preference, this may be considered a weak point.  Enjoyed the platforming, but many are placed at an interval so that you need to be precise in your jumps.  The game does offer a double jump for a skill point that greatly mitigates this challenge.

Bosses:  Uniquely challenging, bosses have good variety and change patterns at specific health levels.  Adds a fun learning curve to the game.

Story:  While interesting, the story takes a passenger role to the game.  In some games, I've wanted to go farther to accomplish a goal.  In this game, searching and defeating enemies to get stronger is far more of an objective.  For me, I only remembered the story when it reminded me.  It wasn't jarring or unwelcome, just I enjoyed the game play so much that my goals played less of a reason for me to play/continue.

Visuals:  Main visuals are on par with expectation, but there is a lot of secondary visuals that make nice touches.  Reflection on glass in background, glowing trails, interesting backgrounds.  It shows a lot of time went into the game.

Secrets:  Unepic style... Even though you can choose a guide to help you know what rooms secrets are in, finding them is still a challenge and sometimes seems unfair.  If you enjoyed how Unepic employed secrets, expect no change.

Things I wish I'd have known earlier.
So.... at the risk of ruining some discovery, I feel it would be an advantage to know some of the following points.  I feel these are important points that I was actually annoyed at the game for not better explaining.

1)  Health is rare, and you do not regenerate at save points.
	Work on learning how you will get health, it’s a precious commodity.  Note there are repair shops.
2)  Items are reusable, even health kits.  
	You will find various items in the game that you can use.  Once used, they don't go away.  You can recharge all items via specific shops.  The more items needing recharged, the more expensive it is to recharge them.
3)  Cubes degrade over time.
	Easily discovered, enemies and crates drop a currency called cubes.  Every few seconds, these degrade in value.  At the beginning of the game, they drop with a 10 value, and degrade to 1 if you wait too long to pick them up.  A good way to prevent sniping in the game since you want to kill enemies at a closer range to get your money's worth.
4) You loose your cubes upon death
	So... you don't get your money's worth if you die though....  This adds great incentive to be careful.
5) You can pickup souls in "ghost" form.
	Everyone, go back to the first boss room and pick up the souls you missed.... You'll thank me for it.
6) When using mouse, scroll wheel will switch weapons.
	Not sure how embarrassed I should be here, this took until first boss to figure out.
7) Breakable walls take damage.
	You can tell if a wall is breakable if it takes damage when you shoot it.  It will usually take more then one shot to break.  Watch carefully when checking for secrets.


Good luck everyone and enjoy the game!!!

[b] Target Audience: [/b] [I] 80s and 90s Scifi/Retro Gaming fans, or those who love metroidvania fans [/i]

[b] Summary: [/b]
It feels like Metroidvania games have had a small resurgence on Steam lately, with games like Rabi-Ribi bringing back feelings of Metroid and Castlevania, despite the original franchises not being treated well by their owners. Luckily, the creator of UnEpic has brought a great little game that understands the strengths of the genre. Now only are there secrets left, right, and pretty much everywhere, but it's fun to explore the environment and to watch the small details that the developer put into the environment. Combat is chaotic, as the randomness of enemies and level design puts you behind the 8 ball at times, as you dodge the reasonable amounts of bullets and threats that the game throw at you. It's the variety that may be the strongest here: and that hits all elements: level, enemy, and boss. Bosses are a spotlight: they are what they should be in this genre: tests of your skills up to that point. And the developer is very responsive: In fact, this review got delayed a day after one of my large negative complains about the game (which I didn't communicate by the way) was fixed. The only real major negative that I have about the game is simple: it crashes a bunch. There seems to be a memory leak if the game is left on for a period of time. But regardless, this is a greatly constructed and well crafted story on top of some great gameplay, and it definitely earns its price of admission.

[b]Video Review: [/b] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rC3_owXXgdg

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*] The chaos of battle can really get the adrenaline going. When you get multiple weapons and you have to switch between them in desperation while at a sliver of life: it can be rather entertaining.
[*] Exploring the environment is fun. There's a great variety 
[*] The 80s/90s retro scifi and gaming references are strong here. If you grew up in that era: you'll love the references all over the place. And the geek powerups: that's a cool way of implementing some nice easter eggs.
[*] And surprisingly, despite the light hearted nature of the writing, it hits some interesting themes and actually makes some great points that resonated with me. The comparison of androids and humans with code and DNA: it's been done before, but the execution here is fantastic.
[*] Several of the laser puzzles take precision that while frustrating if you failed, actually did a great job of keeping the variety of the game up and keeping you on your toes.
[*] Bosses are what they should be: tests of skill and your accumulation of upgrades/talent up to that point.
[*] Upgrades for days, and they all means a lot. Here's a hint though: get the double jump and ghost speed upgrade immediately. You'll thank me. 
[*] There's a lot of detail in the aesthetic. Seeing your own reflection in the glass of the space station was awesome, and despite the pulled back perspective, you can really enjoy the backdrop here.
[*] Secret lovers, you'll love that there's a secret in 2/3rds of the room. Even if that sounds like too much, there's enough variety in the secrets that will keep you interested in that. 
[*] There's a cybernetic frog launcher. It may be shit, but how can this not be a positive. 
[/list]

[*]  If you get frustrated rather easily, this game may give you fits. In particular with some of the laser puzzles in the game. 
[*]  For the secrets however, it could have given some better hints, such as giving environmental indicators (think LoZ bomb walls) to where they were. Some of it is just plain luck that you run across it.

"Ghost, you should totally sneak through this area. Oh shoot, you're going to have to..."

"Shoot? If you say so..." BANG

ALARM ALARM


This developer's previous game was Unepic, a very hit and miss metroidvania cross action RPG homage to roleplaying and pop culture tropes. Ghost 1.0 is made in a simlar vain, but is a massive step up from Unepic, even as it retains some of the silly humour of its predecessor. 

The gameplay is top quality metroidvania fare, with a multitude of power-ups, new skills and over-the-top weapons, tons of hidden secrets to find, interesting boss encounters and areas, several difficulty levels (of which the hardest is challenging without being unfair) and two gameplay modes - standard metroidvania and a "roguelite" setting in which you mostly lose stuff if you die (unless you can loot your corpse). While a little twitchy, the movement and shooting is very smoothly handled, and feels great on mouse and keyboard. 

Sound effects and music are well-done, although I've found the music a little limited, and it repeats often. The voice overs however are absolutely top-notch; I am really impressed with the performances these people have brought to the table. Lines are delivered with passion, and the characters are brought to life. As much as I generally don't like caricatures or silly humour (it's usually delivered poorly), these guys have done things justice in Ghost, with just the right amount of seriousness mixed into the inanity. Great casting work. 

The graphics nail the feel of the futuristic space setting aptly, and the animated cutscenes are well drawn.

I'm only 10 hours in, but wow, am I enjoying this. Ghost 1.0 is incredibly polished, and made by people who clearly love gaming and pop culture history. Amazing work for such a small studio, well worth your money and your time.

Новая игра от разработчика UnEpic. Что ещё можно можно сказать про эту игру... она превосходна! Ну, как минимум первый час. Небольшое ревью по первому часу игры (оставляя за собой право дополнить/исправить/изменить данный обзор)

Геймплейно, и в некоторых моментах идейно, это продолжательница основ, заложенных ещё в UnEpic — Metroidvania-style геймплей и юмор, во многом строящийся на отсылках и сатирой/пародией на гиковскую классику. Теперь объектом для дружеского подтрунивания и оммажа становится научная-фантастика и киберпанк в частности. Главная героиня, Ghost, получает задание, проникнуть на космическую станцию Накамура, украсть сюжетный макгаффин and so on. Вспоминая UnEpic, можно вполне справедливо ожидать неожиданных сюжетных поворотов на 180 градусов, забавные диалоги с горой отсылок и интересных персонажей.

Поменялся сеттинг, изменилась боевая и ролевая механики, но если вы играли в UnEpic, то по большей части в Ghost 1.0 вы будете чувствовать себя как дома. Хоть визуальный дизайн игры и подвергся изменениям в угоду сеттингу, он остался всё таким же простым и понятным как для новичков, так и для матёрых знатоков видеоигр. Геймплейно перед нами всё та же метроидвания, с несколькими вкрапления модной нынче дарк-рогалик-соулс темы — после смерти вы теряете всю нажитую непосильную трудом энергию, местную валюту, а так же все предметы на вашем кибернетическом теле, если вы предварительно не сохранили их на 3D-принтере, местном аналоге точек сохранения.Появились некоторые новые фишки, некоторые из них это переработанные старые, другие же абсолютно новые, но я не буду останавливаться на них подробно, оставляя вам возможность самим увидеть их.

-----

По мере прохождения постараюсь дополнять данный обзор (отдельно дав оценку русской локализации), закончив всё неким финальным вердиктом. Пока что можно сказать одно — покупайте эту игру, она того стоит. Фанат ли вы прошлой игры автора или нет, хардкорный знаток жанра или же совершенно незнакомый с данным пластом видеоигровой культуры человек, это не важно. Ghost 1.0 прекрасно выглядит и играется, и остаётся очень стойкое ощущение, что так всё будет вплоть до финала игры.

23443182.review:
[b]Ghost 1.0 is one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a long time and I would recommend this to absolutely everyone out there.[/b]

I’ll start by saying Unepic was a game I enjoyed a hell of a lot of on GoG so when I heard about Ghost 1.0 to say I was excited is an understatement but it also meant I had very high expectations. How this game managed to go above and beyond will never be something I understand but I am eternally grateful. I think it’s safe to say i’m a bit of a fanboy for the Unepic dev team so bear that in mind going forward.

[b]Story[/b]
If you’ve read my other reviews you’ll know a good story combined with great dialogue makes me very happy and Ghost 1.0 really does have both of these. You play as Ghost, a strange ghostlike being who controls a robot chassis. Set in the future where robots are common, you have been hired by a large corporation (or so you think) to engage in a top secret mission where you find yourself sneaking into a space station to retrieve blueprints and data in regards to the latest most distributed android. Utilizing stealth and combat you’ll find yourself exploring, puzzling and fighting your way through the massive Nakamura space station. The story is very well written and the dialogue is witty and I find myself chuckling often without ever feeling it’s cheesy which is a very fine line in games.

[b]General Gameplay[/b]
If you’ve played Unepic then a lot of Ghost 1.0 will feel familiar to you, and if you haven’t (seriously, why haven’t you? Go and play it now.) then you won’t have to worry, everything is explained to you in a detailed manner and it should come to you very easily after that. You can play using either a controller or kb&m though I've found the controller doesn’t work as smoothly as some things just won’t work for me e.g rolling. You control Ghost, a spectral being in a robot body and must utilize your weapons and survival skills to overcome the various challenges you’ll face. Like other Metroidvania games you'll navigate from room to room clearing out the enemies or solving the puzzles, sometimes both at once.
Ghost has various abilities and weapons at her disposal along with various upgrades and powerups that can be found and bought through the game. There is also a large skill tree which you can level up as you please allowing you to mould the game to your playstyle. Weapons are Ghosts main form of attack and you can buy various different ones for energy cubes in the shops located around the levels equipping up to four at any one time. Along with your weapons you can also have 4 items bound to you hotkeys. Items will offer you small one time perks like regening a small amount of health or recharging your ammo immediately and they run off of charges which can be refilled at most shops. Lastly Ghost can find and buy upgrades which are passives which are automatically activated and cannot be turned off. These are things such as damage boosts or starting with extra energy cubes and can make you very strong as you collect more and more over time because not only do they stack, you can have an unlimited amount. Ghosts second main feature, and a personal favourite of mine, is the ability to posses other androids. This comes in handy for those buttons & platforms you might not be able to reach, but also is rather effective at clearing out rooms of enemies without taking any damage to her own exoskeleton.

Though there is no difficulty setting as such, there are two modes, Classic and Survival, which both differ in difficulty. Survival is more punishing and meant for those who prefer a bit more of a challenge whereas classic focuses on comfortable accessible gameplay.

[b]Graphics and Sound[/b]
The graphics in Ghost 1.0 are fantastic, and everything looks clean and smooth. I love the artwork overall but find myself really, really enjoying the cutscenes. The art in those scenes is very comic book-esque and it’s absolutely brilliant. In fact if the writer and artist got together i’m sure they could make an awesome little webcomic with ease. 
The sound is fitting though I haven’t noticed too much of a soundtrack so far, not that I've felt myself missing it.

[b]Pros[/b]
--- Engaging well written story
--- Great voice acting
--- Large variety of weapons, items, upgrades and powerups
--- Perk(s) if you own Unepic on Steam
--- Very witty/amusing dialogue
--- Probably the best Metroidvania style game I've ever played
--- AWESOME collectables aka Geekies for superficial ingame changes

[b]Cons[/b]
The sound when you travel down a rope. I know this sounds so minor but the sound is awful, so so awful. The only other thing that could possibly be tweaked in my eyes is the amount of healing you find. Not every shop allows you to heal and healing is not easy to come by otherwise meaning you die alot. Since you lose your energy cubes when you die it can become a vicious circle of dying and not being strong enough to advance without buying but not having enough cubes to buy but not surviving long enough to get the cubes etc. Honestly, those are the only issues I can point out right now. I really am loving playing Ghost 1.0 that much so far. 

[b]Summary[/b]
Ghost 1.0 is amazing, it truly is and I can’t recommend this game highly enough. I’ve only put in a few hours so far but since it’s release it’s been the only game I've played. $10 is an unbelieveable price and it’s well worth every single cent so don’t even bother waiting for a sale. Some people were born to create games, Unepic_Fran is one of those people.

Metroid-vania. A somewhat over used term these days, but it fits this game perfectly.

I started on hardcore-Hard mode. So my experience is a mixture of DarkSouls, meets Metroid, meets Castlevania.

As you progress through the game you find alarm beams. If you activate them you get a sort of timed wave based combat fight. If you survive you can activate the panel the alarm was protecting to get money, and gear. 

Gear ranges from passives, to upgrades, to additional weapons. 

On hardcore mode you actually LOSE gear, but leave some gear behind where you died. (that darksouls part i mentioned) 

The other mode allows you to simply play sort of like Super Metroid where you get gear, And just have it as a reserve if it has ammo/is recharged.

It plays like a twin stick and has the BEST controller support I have experienced in years from any game. When you start up you actually get to calibrate all of the buttons you use for the game allowing you to fit the game to how you want to play.  An example of this. Normal shots are RB on a 360controller. And secondary is RT. I swapped the two very easily by just holding RB for the RT calibrate section, and vise versa.

If you want to fulfill your Super Metroid/Castlevania fix, and possibly your darksouls fix too (optional hardcore mode) then I say grab this lovely gem of a game.

Additionally the dialog has been entertaining!


Pros:

Solid gameplay. 
Lots of gear to find.
Secrets. 
Rewards taking risks.
Forgiving or ruthless depending what mode you choose.
Nice music.

Cons.

Some times during alarm phases it is a bit tricky to know if you are being damaged.

23434999.review:
Ghost 1.0 is one of the best modern Metroidvanias you can buy and definitely sits alongside Axiom Verge as a standout of the recently quite crowded genre. Unlike Axiom Verge however which follows the formula to the letter Ghost 1.0 finds its own way and throughout the course of the game constantly throws in surprises and breaks conventions that really make it stand out.

The premise of Ghost 1.0 sees 2 hackers hire a mysterious agent (you) in order to infiltrate the Nakamura Space station in order to learn its secrets. Ghost is an agent capable of taking on the form of an electronic ghost and taking over Androids at will allowing you to control your main android body or a number of other androids around the station and it is this mechanic that really shines through as the game’s unique selling point.

Ghost’s main body is controlled in the usual twin stick shooter style and as you progress through the game you can gain upgrades which give you powerups such as double jump, better weapons and drones to help you fight. Gunplay in the game is fluid and works well with both a controller and a keyboard. One of the main recurring themes of the game sees you stuck in alarmed rooms that gradually increase in level and difficulty as the game progresses and lock you in for a period of time and throw enemies, turrets and mines your way. These are also a great way of saving up energy cubes the game’s currency which allow you to buy new weapons, upgrades and one use items.

One of the key things to note is that upon dying (starting again at one of the save points which are storyline written as robot 3D printers) you lose all of the energy cubes you had amounted. When I started the game I hated this but as I progressed I began to appreciate the sense of risk reward with going into a level 8 or 9 alarm room to try and get more cubes when I could potentially lose my whole stash.

The Nakamura space station is broken up into a number of different zones each opened by finding fragments of a key card spread throughout the previous zone. Alongside these key cards is also a skill point that lets you upgrade either your character, tech, alarm room hacking, your ghost form or even the Nakamura Space station itself in some cases making the game even harder or in the case of the game’s survival mode quicker to advance.

The game can be played in 2 ways. Classic is normal Metroidvania rules with aforementioned penalty of losing all you currency when you die and as you advance through the game you get progressively more powerful. Survival plays more like a roguelike and grants you random powerups quickly as you progress but when you die you lose everything. I much preferred the classic mode but for people wanting a roguelike experience then the game offers this way of playing. One thing I will say is that in classic the game actually becomes easier as you play through the game as you become progressively more powerful and the game is of course setup to take into account people playing in survival mode.

There are lots of secrets to be found including some very cool geeky items my personal favourite being an homage to Metal Gear Solid whenever you die. Most rooms also have souls to collect. These are activated and fill the room with glowing orbs that when collected grant an upgrade, power up, item or cubes. Activating these is a whole game in itself and adds a fun puzzle element to the game’s environments. Even after completing the game I wanted to go back and find all of the souls made easier by handy markers of rooms still to be solved on the map (Something Metroid itself sorely needed when it came to unfound items).

Talking about puzzle solving the game’s come android switching mechanic is often used in the games puzzle sections and plays extremely well. Difficulty is pitched about right and I always felt proud of myself when I solved a puzzle. Difficulty wise the game is an odd one. About half way through the game I was about ready to say how the game’s difficulty curve was vertical (I think I had a headline saying Dark Souls the Metroidvania planned) but in reality the difficulty spike in the middle could be solved simply by doing some more exploring getting a few more cubes and getting better guns and tech. Some of the guns are better than other with a few being incredibly powerful such as the shield which is essentially for beating some of the game’s turret sections and the drone which fills the room with laser beams which makes alarm rooms especially in the later sections of the game much easier. Having said that Ghost 1.0 is not an easy game by any stretch of the imagination.

I never expected to be that drawn into the characters but by the end of the story I was very invested in Ghost and her band of hacker companions. All the game’s cut scenes are fantastically voice acted and get across a lot of heart. All of the protagonists are likeable and the game has a wonderful sense of humour that left me wanting more story at the game’s conclusion.

Overall I absolutely loved playing through Ghost 1.0 and cannot recommend it enough and to fans of the genre is a real must buy. Hopefully Ghost 2.0 is the long term plan because the follow up to Unepic is anything but.

23432034.review:
Ghost 1.0 /Análisis - Un metroidvania cachondo "Made in Spain"

He aquí, 2 años después del lanzamiento de Unepic, la nueva obra de Francisco Téllez de Meneses. 
Ghost 1.0, que así se llama, mantiene la esencia 2D a lo largo de pasillos pero esta vez nos emplaza ante una obra de aventuras de corte futurista donde nos infiltraremos en la estación espacial Nakamura, en la nos esperan hordas y hordas de enemigos robóticos.

Pasamos de un juego retro-retro, como Unepic, a un  juego retro pero adaptado mucho mejor a la actualidad. Se nota que @unepic_fran no hace de “hombre orquesta” por segunda vez, presentando unos valores de producción bastante más altos. 
El motor del juego sigue siendo de confección propia pero esta vez la contratación de un grafista lo hace más resultón, con unos fondos muy detallados que, mezclados con la iluminación y las sombras le dan un toque de profesionalidad.

Ghost 1.0. está completamente doblado al castellano, con un tono tan ameno que resulta reconfortante. El número de voces es bastante amplió y no faltan los “cameos”. 

El sentido de humor sigue muy presente, pero no es la pieza sobre la que gira todo. Esta vez nos encontramos ante un gameplay más rápido donde podremos usar un buen arsenal de armas con sus respectivas mejoras, artefactos  y un árbol de habilidades, que nos irán modificando la forma de jugar según avance la aventura llegando a alcanzar un frenetismo brutal.
 La variedad de niveles, puzles y jefes finales es enorme. Nos encontraremos con habitaciones donde hacer saltar una alarma (la cual irá subiendo de nivel y con ello la dificultad) y enfrentarnos a una horda de defensas de la nave, al más puro estilo “arena”. Estas salas se repetirán a lo largo de la nave, con distinto nivel de “alarma”, variedad de enemigos y distintas configuraciones de escenario que variaran nuestra manera de movernos para salir airosos de entre tantos enemigos. 
El juego nos anima a repetir una y otra vez estas salas para recopilar cubos (que sueltan los enemigos caídos y aparecen en cajas como recompensa a aguantar todas las oleadas), ya que serán la moneda de cambio en las tiendas.
La dificultad es alta y nos trae un cierto sabor a Dark Souls, ya que si morimos perderemos todos los cubos recolectados; y una sala que se nos atraviesa puede suponer un pico de dificultad sin sentido entre secciones por lo demás llevaderas, lo cual puede resultar un poco frustrante -pero reconfortante una vez superado-. Recordad que nos encontramos en una nave llena de defensas, enemigos robóticos, alarmas y trampas… este Fran es un cabroncete!

Por último mencionar que tenemos en mano un título de unas 15 horas de duración en su modo “clásico”, con una gran rejugabilidad, muchos logros, secretos y frikadas varias que harán las delicias de cualquier jugador. El cuidado de los pequeños detalles, como las mecánicas cobran sentido dentro de la historia (el guardado de personaje, por ejemplo) o el nivel de adicción al farmeo de cubos que produce la obra, sin resultada repetitiva, es sin duda síntoma de que nos encontramos ante una obra digna de mención.

¡Gracias Fran por superarte a ti mismo!

I'm a huge fan of Metroid-vania style 2D side scrollers, although most of them tend to be more "Vania" than "Metroid".    This one delivers heavily on the Metroid side, with a story & aesthetic that obviously draws heavily from Ghost in the Shell with some light humor thrown in. Gameplay doesn't have the same kind of straightforward controls that games like Axiom Verge or Dead Cells would have, and they may seem a bit counter-intuitive at first, but it makes sense once you get used to it, especially when running & gunning. All in all, this is one of my favorite games on Steam.  If you're a fan of Axiom Verge, Unepic, or just side scrollers in general, you'll probably like this one.

I'd grade Ghost 1.0 a B. It's a decent, but unessental Metroidvania.

The primary action is running and gunning to survive waves of enemies thrown at you inside locked rooms. There is some light platforming, and the occasional puzzle or opportunity to thin out enemies using the game's posession mechanic, but surviving waves of enemies is the game's bread and butter, as most alarms are completely unavoidable. There is the occasional boss fight as well, one of which was somewhat interesting to figure out.

Although it would be hard to call this game anything other than a Metroidvania, it may be worth mentioning that there aren't any upgrades in the game that allow you to reach or get through anything you couldn't before, besides keycards, which can leave the exploration feeling somewhat linear.

The writing can be hit or miss. It's fully voice acted, which is alright, but at times the cutscenes can drag a bit or a reference to movies or other games will feel a bit forced. Also, the text doesn't always match the voiceover, which can be somewhat jarring.

One unfortunate mechanic is that most powerups that are found throughout the game involve finding something hidden that sprays "souls" all across the room, then running all around the room to gather up the souls. As the gathering can be done in ghost form it's nearly completely without danger, and seems to serve only to waste the player's time. I feel like they should just give you the item. Most of the best upgrades are bought with the in shops as well, with the souls often leading to weak healing items and joke items that toggle references, rather than passive upgrades.
